posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked:
So, for some reason, my code keeps producing weird problems. Today, I was testing our arm’s PID control and at first, it worked perfectly fine, going to the exact position and stopping with minimum oscillation, but after around 45 minutes of testing, the motor just vibrated in place. I tried changing the battery and checking if the motor and gearbox were fine, but they were fine. When I reinstalled the motor and gear box, the motor didn’t even move when I pressed the button. Here’s my code. I based it off of Sushi Squads arm feed forward and PID code:

main/testing-Imported/src/main/java/frc/robot

PLEASEWORK. Contribute to DesteoyerRZSS/3984-2023 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: How did you verify that the motor was fine?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: It was running fine yesterday, and I put it in the rev hardware application and the motor moved when I ran it. Is there something else I should check?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Try the arm with a different motor.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Do you have any other suggestions other than the motor? Is there anything in the software side of things that would cause this?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Ok, so today, I tried the code and I confirmed that it was code, not motor issue. I further narrowed it down to the fact that the PID control was the thing that wasn’t calculating correctly. When I removed the feedforward control, the motor did not move at all when I pressed the trigger. I could not find why the PID was not calculating correctly, and I would appreciate some help.

Have you calculated the arm feedforward starting with gravity kG?

My team will be at this stage soon and my plan of action is:

Calculate kG by holding the arm in air and gently increasing kG until the arm starts to move as reported by the encoder.

Calculate kS by gently increasing it until the arm starts to move.

Assume kV and kA are 0.

Increase kP until oscilates around target.

Increase kD until approach is solid.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: I removed the feedforward value and just had the arm run the pid loop with our feed forward but the shaft didn’t move at all. I’m pretty sure our feedforward part works fine.
